keyTakeAways: Virginia Giuffre, a former Epstein victim, wrote in her posthumous memoir 'Nobody’s Girl' that she was raped and brutally beaten by a 'well-known Prime Minister'—a reference widely interpreted as Prince Andrew.

In the US version of the memoir, the individual is described as a 'well-known Prime Minister'; in the UK version, he is referred to as a 'former minister', creating a discrepancy that may reflect editorial or political sensitivity.
Giuffre alleges that Prince Andrew, who is the brother of King Charles, had sexual encounters with her when she was 17, and that Epstein facilitated these encounters.
Prince Andrew claimed he broke off ties with Epstein in December 2010, but emails from February 2011 suggest he maintained contact, indicating a contradiction.
Andrew’s team allegedly tried to hire online trolls to harass Giuffre during her legal case, a claim that adds to the controversy surrounding his actions.
Giuffre alleges that Andrew paid millions to settle a civil case in 2022, which she views as a form of financial cover-up.

The publication of the memoir intensifies a transatlantic scandal involving the wealthy and powerful, particularly focusing on the close connections between Epstein and high-profile figures like Prince Andrew.
The memoir has deepened the public scrutiny and disgrace of Prince Andrew, who previously announced he would relinquish his title of Duke of York in response to the allegations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Virginia Giuffre, a former victim of Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking ring, published her posthumous memoir 'Nobody’s Girl,' alleging that she was raped and violently beaten by a powerful political figure—described as a 'well-known Prime Minister' in the U.S. version and a 'former minister' in the UK version—widely interpreted as Prince Andrew. The memoir includes claims that Andrew, who is the brother of King Charles, had sexual encounters with Giuffre when she was 17, that Epstein facilitated these encounters, and that Andrew’s team attempted to hire online trolls to harass her during her legal case. Contradictory evidence, including emails from February 2011, suggests Andrew maintained contact with Epstein after claiming to have severed ties in 2010. The publication of the memoir intensifies a transatlantic scandal involving high-profile figures and Epstein, deepening the public disgrace of Prince Andrew, who previously announced he would relinquish his title of Duke of York. This development marks a significant escalation in the ongoing investigation into the connections between powerful individuals and Epstein’s network.
title: Virginia Giuffre raped by ‘well-known Prime Minister,’ US version of posthumous memoir claims
